mainmatter.p: For any frame L, there is a bijection between the set of nuclei on L and the class of maxsets of L.

block.headline: Proof.
block.p: Given a nucleus j : L \to L, we map it to its maxset of fixed points: \mathfrak{F} _j \vcentcolon \equiv \{ x \in L \mid j(x) = x \} , and given a maxset M \subseteq L, we map it to the nucleus defined by j_M(x) \vcentcolon \equiv \bigwedge \left \{ m \in M \mid x \le m \right \} . We need to show that these give a section-retraction pair.

Let j : L \to L be a nucleus. We need to show j = j_{ \mathfrak{F} _j}. For the ( \le ) direction, notice that for every x \in L, j(x) \le \bigwedge \{ y \in \mathfrak{F} _j \mid x \le y \} must be the case since j(x) is clearly a lower bound of \{ y \in \mathfrak{F} _j \mid x \le y \}.
Let M be a maxset. We need to show M = \mathfrak{F} _{j_M}.

mainmatter.p: Let L be a frame and j : L \to L a nucleus on it. The set of fixed points of j forms a maxset.

Let S \subseteq \mathfrak{F} _j. mainmatter.p:
Let L be a frame. A nucleus on L is an endofunction j : L \to L satisfying the following three conditions.
Meet preservation: \forall x, y \in L. \ j(x \wedge y) = j(x) \wedge j(y).
Inflationarity: \forall x \in L. \ x \le j(x).
Idempotence: \forall x \in L. j(j(x)) \le j(x).
